segment.source: Authentication of MED-V End Users
segment.target: Authentication of MED-V End Users

segment.source: The authentication of Microsoft Enterprise Desktop Virtualization (MED-V) 2.0 end users is a very important security issue.
segment.target: The authentication of Microsoft Enterprise Desktop Virtualization (MED-V) 2.0 end users is a very important security issue.

segment.source: In this context, authentication refers to verifying the identity of the MED-V end user.
segment.target: In this context, authentication refers to verifying the identity of the MED-V end user.

segment.source: The following section provides information and guidance about end-user authentication in MED-V.
segment.target: The following section provides information and guidance about end-user authentication in MED-V.

segment.source: User Authentication in MED-V
segment.target: User Authentication in MED-V

segment.source: Authentication in MED-V generally occurs at two levels: when a user first accesses MED-V and every time that they change their password.
segment.target: Authentication in MED-V generally occurs at two levels: when a user first accesses MED-V and every time that they change their password.

segment.source: Depending on how you have configured MED-V settings for authentication, the end user is typically prompted at some point to enter their password, either the first time MED-V is started or the first time that they try to open a published application.
segment.target: Depending on how you have configured MED-V settings for authentication, the end user is typically prompted at some point to enter their password, either the first time MED-V is started or the first time that they try to open a published application.

segment.source: There are several aspects of end-user authentication that you can control, including the following:
segment.target: There are several aspects of end-user authentication that you can control, including the following:

segment.source: Whether the credentials the end user enters are stored in Credential Manager
segment.target: Whether the credentials the end user enters are stored in Credential Manager

segment.source: In what manner the end user is presented with the option of entering and saving their password
segment.target: In what manner the end user is presented with the option of entering and saving their password

segment.source: Depending on your company’s preferred process for managing end-user authentication, you can specify whether credential caching occurs for a particular MED-V workspace.
segment.target: Depending on your company’s preferred process for managing end-user authentication, you can specify whether credential caching occurs for a particular MED-V workspace.

segment.source: Caching the credentials of an end user is helpful because they are only prompted one time for their password.
segment.target: Caching the credentials of an end user is helpful because they are only prompted one time for their password.

segment.source: If the end user is not allowed to save their password or they decide not to, every time that they start a new MED-V session, they must enter it again.
segment.target: If the end user is not allowed to save their password or they decide not to, every time that they start a new MED-V session, they must enter it again.

segment.source: For example, if MED-V is configured to start when the end user logs on to the host but Authentication is disabled, the end user is only prompted one time during logon.
segment.target: For example, if MED-V is configured to start when the end user logs on to the host but Authentication is disabled, the end user is only prompted one time during logon.

segment.source: In this case, credentials are valid until the end user logs off from the host.
segment.target: In this case, credentials are valid until the end user logs off from the host.

segment.source: If it is necessary, you can use Credential Manager to remove any stored end-user credentials.
segment.target: If it is necessary, you can use Credential Manager to remove any stored end-user credentials.

segment.source: By default, credential storing is disabled, but you can change this setting through one of the following methods:
segment.target: By default, credential storing is disabled, but you can change this setting through one of the following methods:

segment.source: While you are creating the MED-V workspace package.
segment.target: While you are creating the MED-V workspace package.

segment.source: For more information, see Create a MED-V Workspace Package.
segment.target: For more information, see Create a MED-V Workspace Package.

segment.source: After you have deployed the MED-V workspace.
segment.target: After you have deployed the MED-V workspace.

segment.source: Edit the MED-V cmdlet parameter UxCredentialCacheEnabled to set the Terminal Services registry key.
segment.target: Edit the MED-V cmdlet parameter UxCredentialCacheEnabled to set the Terminal Services registry key.

segment.source: For more information, see Windows PowerShell Help.
segment.target: For more information, see Windows PowerShell Help.

segment.source: After MED-V workspace deployment, you can set your preference for end-user authentication by modifying the Terminal Services policy named DisablePasswordSaving.
segment.target: After MED-V workspace deployment, you can set your preference for end-user authentication by modifying the Terminal Services policy named DisablePasswordSaving.

segment.source: DisablePasswordSaving controls whether the password saving check box appears on the RDP client dialog window and whether the MED-V credential prompt is displayed.
segment.target: DisablePasswordSaving controls whether the password saving check box appears on the RDP client dialog window and whether the MED-V credential prompt is displayed.

segment.source: Following is the policy path for the Terminal Services policy named DisablePasswordSaving.
segment.target: Following is the policy path for the Terminal Services policy named DisablePasswordSaving.

segment.source: Regedit:
segment.target: Regedit:

segment.source: HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftVirtual MachinePoliciesDisablePasswordSaving
segment.target: HKEYLOCALMACHINESOFTWAREMicrosoftVirtual MachinePoliciesDisablePasswordSaving

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The changes that you make to DisablePasswordSaving only affect the RDP prompt to a virtual machine.
segment.target: The changes that you make to DisablePasswordSaving only affect the RDP prompt to a virtual machine.

segment.target: The following table lists the different ways you can configure your settings for credential storing and the effects of the different configurations:

segment.target: DisablePasswordSaving

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: The MED-V prompt is presented and a check box to accept is available and cleared.
segment.target: The MED-V prompt is presented and a check box to accept is available and cleared.

segment.source: If the end user selects the check box, credentials are cached for subsequent use.
segment.target: If the end user selects the check box, credentials are cached for subsequent use.

segment.source: The end user also has the benefit of only being prompted when the password expires.
segment.target: The end user also has the benefit of only being prompted when the password expires.

segment.source: If the end user does not select the check box, the Remote Desktop Connection (RDC) Client prompt is presented instead of the MED-V prompt, and the check box to accept is cleared.
segment.target: If the end user does not select the check box, the Remote Desktop Connection (RDC) Client prompt is presented instead of the MED-V prompt, and the check box to accept is cleared.

segment.source: If the end user selects the check box, the RDC Client credential is stored for later use.
segment.target: If the end user selects the check box, the RDC Client credential is stored for later use.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: RDC does not validate credentials when the end user enters them.
segment.target: RDC does not validate credentials when the end user enters them.

segment.source: If the end user caches the credentials through the RDC prompt, there is a risk that incorrect credentials might be stored.
segment.target: If the end user caches the credentials through the RDC prompt, there is a risk that incorrect credentials might be stored.

segment.source: In this case, the incorrect credentials must be deleted in the Windows Credential Manager.
segment.target: In this case, the incorrect credentials must be deleted in the Windows Credential Manager.

segment.source: DisablePasswordSaving
segment.target: DisablePasswordSaving

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: This configuration is more secure because it does not allow end user credentials to be cached.
segment.target: This configuration is more secure because it does not allow end user credentials to be cached.

segment.source: By default, the MED-V installation sets a registry key in the guest to suppress the "password about to expire" prompt.
segment.target: By default, the MED-V installation sets a registry key in the guest to suppress the "password about to expire" prompt.

segment.source: The end user is only prompted for a password change on the host.
segment.target: The end user is only prompted for a password change on the host.

segment.source: Credentials that are updated on the host are passed to the guest.
segment.target: Credentials that are updated on the host are passed to the guest.

segment.source: Caution
segment.target: Caution

segment.source: If you use Group Policy in your environment, know that it can override the registry key causing the password prompts from the guest to reappear.
segment.target: If you use Group Policy in your environment, know that it can override the registry key causing the password prompts from the guest to reappear.

segment.source: Security Concerns with Authentication
segment.target: Security Concerns with Authentication

segment.source: Even though caching the end user’s credentials provides the best user experience, you must be aware of the risks involved.
segment.target: Even though caching the end user’s credentials provides the best user experience, you must be aware of the risks involved.

segment.source: When credential caching is enabled, the end user’s domain credential is stored in a reversible format within the Windows Credential Manager.
segment.target: When credential caching is enabled, the end user’s domain credential is stored in a reversible format within the Windows Credential Manager.

segment.source: As a result, an attacker could write a tool that runs as either a system level process or an end user process and that retrieves the end user's credentials.
segment.target: As a result, an attacker could write a tool that runs as either a system level process or an end user process and that retrieves the end user's credentials.

segment.source: You can only lessen this risk by setting DisablePasswordSaving to Enabled.
segment.target: You can only lessen this risk by setting DisablePasswordSaving to Enabled.

segment.source: This same concern exists when MED-V authentication is disabled but the Terminal Services policy setting is enabled.
segment.target: This same concern exists when MED-V authentication is disabled but the Terminal Services policy setting is enabled.
